articles.title: The Path to a German University: A Practical Guide for Arab 48 Students
articles.description: From Bagrut to university admission — every step explained
articles.content:
If you've finished your Bagrut and decided to study in Germany, the first thing you need to understand is that the Israeli high school diploma isn't always directly recognized. In most cases, you'll need to complete a preparatory year (Studienkolleg) before starting university.

The first step is applying through uni-assist — the central institution that evaluates your credentials and determines if you qualify for direct admission or need to go through the preparatory program.

Ideal Timeline:
• 12 months before: Start learning German (aim for B1 minimum)
• 8 months before: Prepare documents — Bagrut transcript, certified translations, passport
• 6 months before: Apply through uni-assist (fees around €75)
• 4 months before: Receive admission and begin visa procedures

Darb's tip: Don't wait for your final Bagrut results to start preparing. Begin language learning and document collection as early as possible. Many of our students lost an entire semester because they started late.

articles.title: German Student Visa Step by Step: From Appointment to Stamp
articles.description: Embassy procedures, blocked account, insurance — everything detailed
articles.content:
As an Israeli passport holder, the student visa process for Germany is relatively straightforward but requires organization.

Required Documents:
• Valid passport (at least 6 months validity)
• University acceptance letter or Studienkolleg admission
• Financial proof: Blocked account (Sperrkonto) of €11,904 annually (2025)
• Health insurance (we recommend TK or AOK for students)
• German language certificate (B1 minimum)

How to Book an Embassy Appointment:
The German Embassy in Tel Aviv — book online through the embassy website. Appointments fill up fast, so try booking at least 3 months ahead.

Blocked Account (Sperrkonto):
Most popular banks: Expatrio or Fintiba. The process is online and takes 3-5 business days. Transfer the amount and receive confirmation for the embassy.

Darb's tip: Prepare a complete, organized file. The embassy can reject your application if documents are missing. Our team helps review your file before the appointment.

articles.title: Your First 30 Days in Germany: What Nobody Tells You
articles.description: Anmeldung, bank, SIM card, transport — the real starter guide
articles.content:
Arrived in Germany? Congratulations! But your first month is the most important and most challenging. Here's your essential checklist:

1. Anmeldung (Address Registration): Within 14 days of arrival, visit the Bürgeramt to register your address. Without this, you can't open a bank account or get insurance.

2. Open a Bank Account: We recommend N26 (online and fast) or Sparkasse (branches everywhere). You'll need your passport and Anmeldung confirmation.

3. Phone SIM Card: Aldi Talk or Lidl Connect — cheapest options that work well. Activation requires a video call with your passport.

4. Transport: Deutschlandticket for €49/month — gets you everywhere by train and bus.

5. Health Insurance: Register immediately. Without insurance, you can't enroll at university.

Culture Shock? It's Normal:
- Germans value punctuality — arriving 5 minutes late can be an issue
- Shops are closed on Sundays — shop beforehand!
- People may seem cold at first but it's their style, not disrespect

Darb's tip: Join our WhatsApp group for new students — you'll find instant help from students who've been through it all.

articles.title: German Language: From Zero to B1 — A Realistic Plan
articles.description: Institutes, apps, and tips specifically for Arabic speakers
articles.content:
The German language is the key to your academic and social life in Germany. The good news: as an Arabic speaker, you have an advantage — many German sounds exist in Arabic.

A Realistic Plan to Reach B1 in 6-8 Months:

Months 1-2 (A1):
• Enroll in a language school (Goethe Institut or local institute)
• 4-5 hours of study daily
• Use Duolingo and Anki for vocabulary

Months 3-4 (A2):
• Start listening to simple German podcasts (Slow German)
• Watch German series with subtitles (Dark, How to Sell Drugs Online)
• Practice conversation with a Tandem partner

Months 5-6 (B1):
• Focus on advanced grammar (Konjunktiv II, Passiv)
• Write daily — even simple sentences
• Enroll in a B1 exam preparation course

Required Language Exams:
• Goethe-Zertifikat: Most widely accepted
• TestDaF: Required by universities (B2-C1 level)
• DSH: Taken at the university itself after arrival

Darb's tip: Don't wait until you arrive in Germany to start learning. Every day you start earlier saves you a month there.

articles.title: Student Housing in Germany: How to Find an Apartment Without Losing Your Mind
articles.description: Studentenwerk, WG-Gesucht, city prices, and avoiding scams
articles.content:
Finding housing in Germany — especially in big cities — can be a real challenge. But with the right planning, you'll manage.

Types of Housing:
1. Student Dorm (Studentenwohnheim): Cheapest (€200-350/month). Apply through Studierendenwerk as soon as you receive admission — waiting lists are long!
2. Shared Apartment (WG): Most popular among students (€300-500). WG-Gesucht.de is the main platform.
3. Private Apartment (€500-800+): More expensive but more privacy.

Rent by City (Monthly Average):
• Heidelberg: €350-450
• Münster: €300-400
• Düsseldorf: €400-550
• Berlin: €400-600
• Munich: €500-750

⚠️ Watch Out for Scams:
• Never transfer money before seeing the apartment (even via video)
• If the offer seems too cheap — it's probably a scam
• Don't use Western Union for payment
• Trusted platform: WG-Gesucht.de only

Darb's tip: We offer housing assistance — we contact landlords and arrange everything before you arrive.

articles.title: Real Living Costs in Germany 2025: A Detailed Monthly Budget
articles.description: Rent, food, transport, insurance — real numbers by city
articles.content:
Many websites tell you living in Germany is cheap. The truth? It depends on the city and your lifestyle.

Realistic Monthly Budget (Medium City like Heidelberg or Münster):

• Rent (WG): €350-400
• Food & groceries: €200-250
• Health insurance: €120 (for students)
• Deutschlandticket: €49
• Phone & internet: €15-25
• Personal needs: €50
• Entertainment: €50-100

Total: €834-994/month

Comparison with Expensive Cities:
• Munich: Add €150-200 to rent
• Berlin: Add €50-100
• Eastern Germany (Leipzig, Dresden): Save €100-150

How to Save:
• Cook at home — eating out is expensive
• Use discount apps: Too Good To Go, Lidl Plus
• Buy second-hand: eBay Kleinanzeigen for furniture and appliances
• The blocked account gives you ~€992/month — enough if you budget well

Darb's tip: Use our Cost Calculator to get a customized estimate for your city and major.
